Award.AwardTitle: USC Robert Noyce Science Teacher Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the Biology Department and the School of Education of the University of Southern California have formed a partnership with the Los Angeles Natural History Museum and the Los Angeles Unified School District 7 to offer scholarships to prepare 50 science majors to become high-school science teachers. Known as Robert Noyce Scholars, these undergraduate students are trained in formal and informal pedagogic methods while developing expertise in their subject so that, once certified, they can provide high-quality science education to students in high-need school districts such as the partner district. A unique feature of the program is the MAT@USC, an online teacher education program that involves a large number of pre-service teachers across the nation as well as a smaller number on campus. The Scholars, scattered among centers in San Diego, New York, Sacramento, and Seattle as well as Los Angeles, remain in contact with the Robert Noyce Science Teacher Scholarship Program through the Urban Science Teacher Network, which connects current and former scholars on line to discuss and share aspects of their experiences as science educators. This opportunity for daily support is expected to improve the long-term retention of the teachers in challenging classrooms settings. Contributions to the literature on education are drawn from assessments of the impact of the network on retention and new ideas that the group as a whole develop on the topic of appropriate pedagogy for the urban setting. The impact is more broadly felt, too, in the opportunity for students to learn science in new ways and with greater understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
USC Noyce Science Teacher Scholarship Program 2011-2019

 

In 2011, USC applied for a Noyce Grant to support scholars from diverse backgrounds in completing their online science MAT program. At the time, a new Learning Management System (LMS) had been adopted and customized to accommodate scholars from across the country and the tools and opportunities for developing new science teachers seemed vast. After being awarded the grant and implementing the program, much was learned in terms of the strengths and challenges for recruiting new scholars, retaining them in science teaching within high-needs schools, and also in terms of the ways in which the LMS could provide additional learning and collaboration.  Two of the most significant outcomes of this award include hosting a Noyce Regional Dialogue and participating in the Noyce Summit Voices from the Field Panal (Kearstyie Hernandez).  Here, we briefly outline the outcomes of this USC Noyce Project.

 

Target and Recruit Science Majors of diverse backgrounds that are committed to teaching science in our urban partner districts into our program.

●      In order attract science majors of diverse background the team at USC primarily leveraged the advertising of 2U, the company that developed the Learning Management System (LMS) for the MAT program. Advertising was prolific on Facebook, Google, and other social media venues. Once information was gathered about the candidate interest and background, then 2U or one of the USC Noyce team reached out directly to that person. Those candidates were subsequently introduced to current students in the program, and after the first year to scholars in the current Noyce cohorts. The result of these recruitment strategies resulted in a very diverse group of USC Noyce Science Scholars.

 

 

Prepare our MAT@USC Scholars to teach science using inquiry to urban children.

●      While all teachers completed the same curriculum, we were hopeful that we could use both their classwork, their student teaching, and their edTPA to inform the ways we support them through their time at USC and upon entering the field as novice teachers; however, much of the teaching and learning remained limited to within each individual course. In the re-designed MAT Program, the curriculum has changed to integrate the pedagogy course with the student teaching, hopefully leading toward richer conversations about student inquiry and student learning. In the final two years of the grant the MAT Program was re-designed to integrate fieldwork and coursework, with an emphasis on video case studies to develop science teacher practice.

 

Retain and matriculate the MAT@USC Noyce scholars in our partner schools while helping them develop their inquiry based teaching practice and improve their students? achievement.

●      One hundred percent of our Noyce Scholars are on the path to fulfilling their Noyce obligations and only two of the forty six have left the science teaching profession. 

●      Challenges and Suggestions. While we know that all of the USC Noyce scholars transitioned to high needs schools upon completing their degree, maintaining communication with these alumni, was difficult. While some insight has been gathered through alumni participation in monthly meetings, little is known about their teaching practice in the field or the rates of success of their students. In the future, it would be ideal to integrate sharing of work more explicitly during the monthly meetings and to arrange visits to alumni in the years subsequent to their graduating.

 

Support the recruitment, preparation, and retention of the MAT@USC scholars by implementing the online Urban Science Teacher Network (USTN). AND Use the USTN to convene scientists, mentors, science educators, and Noyce scholars in authentic discussion of teaching and learning science.

●      The USTN was used primarily to support the pedagogy of the scholars and it was minimally inclusive of scientists or mentors. Because it was established as a learning community, scholars both gained from participating and contributed to the learning of their classmates. Science educators structured some conversations, but scholars also shared resources that they gathered from NSTA, NASA, and Project Lead the Way, among others. The  majority of scholars self-reported that science content knowledge was already a strength and knew ways of reaching out directly to scientists themselves, so bringing expert scientists into the forum felt less necessary.

●      Challenges and Suggestions. The greatest challenge was getting alumni to participate. The PIs expressed a strong desire to have alumni and current scholars work together in this community, as it is believed that the mutual learning would be beneficial. Over the course of the grant, we tried a variety of online platforms to engage our Noyce community (Playground, USC LMS and Google Hangouts).   Our evaluation revealed that none of these plateforms met the needs of our Scholars.   In the final year of the grant, we began using Edthena and the last cohort of scholars reported that sharing their science teaching practice in this forum was extremely beneficial.
